questions.text: If father's blood group is A and mother's blood group is B, the child's blood group will be
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • There are four phenotypes and six genotypes in blood group inheritance.
  • If the father is phenotype A (genotype AA or AO) and the mother is phenotype B (genotype BB or BO), the possible offspring genotypes are AB, AO, BO, or OO.
  • These correspond to phenotypes AB, A, B, or O.
  • A and B are both dominant, O is recessive to both, and A and B are co-dominant.
  • Phenotypes: A, B, AB, O.
  • Genotypes: AA, AO, BB, BO, AB, OO.
  • Co-dominance: A and B alleles express equally when together.
  • Recessive: O allele expresses only when paired with another O.

A only (Option A): This is possible only if the child inherits the A allele from the father and the O allele from the mother - but it is not the only possibility.

B only (Option B): This is possible if the child inherits the B allele from the mother and the O allele from the father - but other outcomes are possible.

AB only (Option C): This occurs if the child inherits A from the father and B from the mother - but it's not the only possible phenotype.

questions.text: Identical twins will not have same
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Identical twins share the same DNA fingerprint pattern, HLA system, and blood group.
  • However, their fingerprint patterns differ because fingerprints are formed due to both genetic and intrauterine environmental factors.
  • This makes fingerprints a reliable method of distinguishing between identical twins.
  • Fingerprints: Unique even in identical twins.

DNA fingerprint pattern (Option B): Same in identical twins because they share identical genetic material.

HLA system (Option C): Same due to identical genetic origin.

Blood group (Option D): Same because it is genetically determined.

questions.text: Karyotyping of foetus may be done from all of the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Karyotyping involves arranging and analyzing chromosomes to detect abnormalities in number or structure.
  • The process requires cells capable of division so they can be arrested in metaphase, where chromosomes are most visible.
  • Monocytes are non-dividing cells and therefore cannot be used for karyotyping.
  • Purpose: Detects chromosomal number abnormalities (e.g., trisomy 21) and structural abnormalities (e.g., deletions, translocations, inversions).
  • Common fetal sources for karyotyping:
    • Lymphocytes (from fetal blood) (Option B ruled out)
    • Fibroblasts (from skin biopsy) (Option C ruled out)
    • Amniocytes (from amniotic fluid via amniocentesis) (Option D ruled out)
  • Monocytes: Terminally differentiated white blood cells that do not undergo division → unsuitable for karyotyping.

Reference: https://www.nature.com/scitable/topicpage/karyotyping-for-chromosomal-abnormalities-298

questions.text: Phadebas test is used to detect
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Phadebas test (also known as the Phadebas Forensic Press Test or Phadebas amylase test) is a presumptive, enzyme-based colorimetric assay primarily used for detecting saliva on forensic exhibits.
  • It works by identifying α-amylase activity, which is present in high concentration in human saliva.
  • The test medium (paper or tablets) contains starch microspheres bound to a blue dye; when α-amylase is present, starch is hydrolyzed, releasing the dye and producing a visible blue color.
  • It is sensitive and effective at room temperature, but not fully specific, as α-amylase can occur in other body fluids at much lower concentrations.
  • Buccal squamous cells in the sample can help confirm saliva presence.
  • Colostrum detection: Trypsin inhibitor test. (Option B ruled out)
  • Milk detection: Casein and lactose detection. (Option A ruled out)
  • Urine detection: Urea and creatinine tests. (Option D ruled out)
  • Phadebas tube test → higher sensitivity for weak or mixed stains; press test → localizes stains on items like fabrics.
  • Interpretation must consider possible cross-reactivity (e.g., with vaginal secretions, urine, or blood).

Key Takeaways:

  • Phadebas test → detects α-amylase, presumptive for saliva.
  • Results must be confirmed due to potential cross-reactivity.
  • Saliva detection can also be supported by microscopic identification of buccal epithelial cells.

Reference: https://www.phadebas.com/products/forensic-saliva-test-products

questions.text: The term MERMER is related to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Brain fingerprinting, developed by Lawrence Farwell, is a forensic technique that uses electroencephalography (EEG) to determine whether specific information is stored in a subject's brain.
  • It relies on detecting a distinctive brainwave pattern called P300-MERMER (Memory and Encoding Related Multifaceted Electroencephalographic Response), which appears when the brain recognizes meaningful, stored information.

In the test, the subject is shown crime-relevant (probe), irrelevant, and target stimuli on a computer screen while EEG records brain activity.

  • P300 → Initial recognition response.
  • MERMER → P300 plus additional late negative-positive brainwave components, giving higher accuracy than P300 alone.
  • MERMER-based brain fingerprinting can distinguish "information present" from "information absent" with up to 99.9% statistical confidence in controlled settings.
  • It detects recognition of specific information, not lies or stress, making it more resistant to countermeasures than polygraphy.
  • Validated studies by the FBI, CIA, and US Navy report near-100% accuracy with no false positives/negatives when protocols are followed.

Key distinctions:

  • Narcoanalysis → Uses drugs to lower inhibition. (Option B ruled out)
  • DNA fingerprinting → Identifies individuals via genetic markers. (Option C ruled out)
  • Polygraph → Measures physiological responses to detect stress or deception. (Option D ruled out)
  • Brain fingerprinting (MERMER) → Detects stored knowledge via EEG brainwaves.

Key Takeaway:

MERMER is a specific EEG signature central to brain fingerprinting, enabling highly accurate forensic detection of concealed knowledge.

questions.text: ABO antigens are found in all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • About 80% of the population are "secretors" and secrete ABO blood group antigens (also called ABH antigens) into various body fluids, while 20% are "non-secretors" and do not secrete them.
  • In secretors, these antigens are present in saliva, sweat, and gastric juice, but are absent in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) even in secretors.

Saliva (Option A): ABO antigens are present in secretors.

Sweat (Option B): ABO antigens can be detected in sweat of secretors..

Gastric juice (Option D): ABH antigens are found in gastric juice of secretors

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for blood grouping in old blood stain on cloth?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For ABO blood grouping in old dried stains on cloth, the absorption-elution (AE) technique is the method of choice.

  • It works by adsorbing specific antibodies to the antigens in the stain, then eluting them with heat, and testing for agglutination with known red cells.
  • AE is highly sensitive and specific, effective even for stains stored for months, and works with very small samples such as threads

Forensic serology uses different tests depending on the aim:

  • Presumptive tests for blood detection (e.g., benzidine, phenolphthalein, luminol) only detect the presence of blood and are not suitable for blood grouping. (Option A ruled out)
  • Confirmatory tests (e.g., Teichmann's haemin crystal, Takayama's haemochromogen) identify hemoglobin but do not determine blood type. (Option C ruled out)
  • Precipitin test is used to identify the species of the blood, not the ABO group. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Which of the following tests is used to detect semen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Barberio's test is a presumptive test for semen detection.
  • It identifies spermine by forming yellow needle-shaped crystals of spermine picrate.
  • This test is still recognized in forensic serology as part of the screening process for seminal stains, including dried samples.
  • Other important semen tests:
    • Presumptive tests:
      • Seminal Acid Phosphatase (SAP): Most common initial test.
      • UV light: Semen stains fluoresce blue-white.
      • Florence test: Detects choline iodide (dark brown rhombic crystals).
      • PSA (p30): Highly specific, detectable in stains up to 10 years old.
      • TLC: Detects both choline and spermine.
    • Confirmatory tests:
      • Microscopy for spermatozoa.
      • Electrophoresis for sperm-specific LDH isoenzyme.
      • FISH for Y chromosomes.
      • Zinc and CPK tests (old stains).
      • RSID for semenogelin (Sg).

Marsh test (Option A): Detects arsenic.

Phenolphthalein test (Option B): Detects blood.

Paraffin test (Option C): Detects gunpowder residues.

questions.text: The only test to detect both choline and spermine in seminal stain is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Thin layer chromatography detects both choline and spermine in seminal stain.

Thin layer chromatography:

  • TLC is a method that separates and identifies both choline and spermine simultaneously in semen samples.
  • Extract the stain (usually with 1 N HCl), apply a small sample to a silica TLC plate, and allow it to spread in a solvent system.
  • After separation, apply reagents: Dragendorff's reagent highlights choline, while potassium iodoplatinate reveals spermine.

Florence test:

  • The stain is extracted by 1 % hydrochloric acid and a drop is placed on a glass slide.
  • A drop of Florence solution (Postassium iodine, iodine and water) is allowed to run under the cover slip.
  • If semen is present, dark-brown crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.
  • They are rhombic crystals resembling haemin.
  • A negative test means the fluid is not semen.

Barberio's test:

  • A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid when added to spermatic fluid, produces yellow needle shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate.
  • In Barberio's test, the presence of spermine in semen is detected.

The Acid phosphatase test:

  • Acid phosphatase activity of human semen per ml is 340 - 360 Bodansky units or 2500 - 3500 Angstorm units.
  • It is the most commonly used presumptive test for the detection of seminal fluid.
  • The prostatic secretion element of seminal fluid contains a very much higher percentage of acid phosphatase.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with a history of perianal pain is brought to the OPD. On subjecting the specimen from the perianal region to a test, it produces yellow rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The test done in the scenario is the Barberio test.

Barberio's test:

  • Used to detect: Semen.
  • Stain used: Saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid.
  • Finding: If semen is present, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate

Florence test (Option B):

  • Used to detect: Semen.
  • Stain used: 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water)
  • Finding: If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystalsof choline iodide appear immediately

Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test)(Option C):

  • Used to detect: Bloodstains.
  • Stain used: Takayama reagent (sodium hydroxide. pyridine, glucose)
  • Finding: If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystalsof hemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes

Teichmann's test (Haemin crystal Test) (Option D):

  • Used to detect: Bloodstains.
  • Stain used: Glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride.
  • Finding: If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish red to brownish-black rhombic crystalsof haemin or haematin chloride appear
